Only one piece of advice .. Don't move to java 😂😂😂
Learn the basics of MVC very well, understand ORM's such as hibernate
Get to know the lucene family

Java EE is shit,  I have yet to see a successful website that uses it. 

And no, corporate websites don't count.
Spring Framework, JPA, Junit, Mockito (for unit testing too), Maven (build automation tool)
If it's a decision based on personal preference, then Don't :D

Java is superior to the MS alternative in the following aspects:
1. A multitude of frameworks,  (MS there is mainly one)
2. Design patterns in Java implemented for better decoupling
3. You can actually view the code that was written in the Java Libraries by Gosling and others (a great opportunity)
4. Spring framework is a great way to learn MVC, DI and many other concepts at a deeper level than you would with .NET (I used both)
5. The AOP in Java is very mature and powerful
6. Java is the number one language worldwide for Job seekers.
I forgot to mention the framework options are in the ORM, UNIT TESTING, and UI level.
The point where .NET world has advantage, is ease to get started and C# has better lambdas

Java is also great because it is ope source and Free, meaning you can have totally free tools that are enterprise grade like Eclipse and the LAMP stack on Linux, you will also get better container support if you run Java on Docker on Linux. And all this for FREE not a single cent, you just download, install and enjoy. :)

I've been working mostly with Java since 1999 till today (but also worked with PHP, RoR, Python, C/C++, .NET). If there is a single advice I would give anyone starting their software development career, it would be: Be a software engineer and never be biased to any language. Master the basics of computer science like data structures and algorithms and master one language really very well and then learn more languages as much as you can. PHP has tons of jobs and so is Java, Python and so are many others -  none of them is disappearing soon I guess. However good companies would be looking for good software engineers who know how to create high quality usable software. Having said that and back to the original question, trends that I see now are Big Data, Analytics, and IoT as far as I know but better to find good sources for good companies such as Gartener or LinkedIn who do research based on Business trends or job markets These are trends that are having growth now however old mainstream is there and will continue to exist. All the best!
The idea is pick one language and platform for a while to learn the concepts deeply, so that the syntax disappears but the understanding remains.
